content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring border security operations are carried out. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as "Indian tribe" as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of Homeland Security, and "Secretary Concerned" based on the relevant land jurisdiction. The Secretary of Agriculture, Interior, Defense, or Commerce has jurisdiction over specific lands. SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. The Border Protection Strategy requires multiple secretaries to develop and submit a comprehensive plan to Congress by September 30, 2009, in consultation with various officials. The strategy must include a comparative analysis of border security levels. The Border Protection Strategy mandates the development and submission of a comprehensive plan to Congress by multiple secretaries by September 30, 2009. The strategy must include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through various security measures, including pedestrian fencing. The Border Protection Strategy requires a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through various security measures, including pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, and natural barriers. The Border Protection Strategy includes analyzing the effectiveness of vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers, and advanced technology for border security. The Border Protection Strategy includes the use of advanced remote sensing technology, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other advanced systems for surveillance and response analysis in challenging terrains and adverse conditions. The Border Protection Strategy involves using advanced technology for surveillance and response analysis in difficult terrains and adverse conditions, as well as enhancing cooperation with intelligence, security, and law enforcement agencies in Mexico and Canada. The Border Protection Strategy includes using advanced technology for surveillance in challenging terrains, enhancing cooperation with intelligence agencies in Mexico and Canada, and removing obstructive vegetation. The Border Protection Strategy involves detecting, reporting, analyzing, and responding to unauthorized border crossings from Mexico or Canada, as well as removing obstructive vegetation. Cost and impact analysis of security measures are also included. The comprehensive analysis of cost and impacts of security measures includes land acquisition, construction, maintenance over 25 years, contractor, management, overhead costs, and impacts on wildlife. Construction costs, maintenance costs over 25 years, contractor costs, management and overhead costs, and impacts on wildlife and hydrology are considered in the analysis of security measures. The analysis considers the impacts on wildlife habitats, water quality, quantity, and hydrological flows, as well as the costs of mitigating these impacts on Federal, tribal, State, local, and private lands along the border. The analysis includes the costs of fully mitigating adverse impacts to Federal, tribal, State, local, and private lands, waters, wildlife, and habitats, including the replacement or restoration of wildlife migration corridors. The full costs of replacing or restoring severed wildlife migration corridors with protected corridors of equivalent biological functionality, as determined by relevant authorities, including impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life for residents in the vicinity. The curr_chunk discusses the consultation with tribal, State, and local governments, as well as authorities of Mexico and Canada, regarding the impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life near the border. It also includes a compilation of fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters related to the area. The curr_chunk focuses on the fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters near the border for conservation purposes, including protected wildlife migration corridors. The curr_chunk discusses lands near the U.S. borders managed for conservation purposes in various federal agencies like the National Park System, National Forest System, Bureau of Land Management, and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The curr_chunk lists different types of land under the jurisdiction of various federal agencies, including the National Park System, National Forest System, Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Department of the Interior, Department of Agriculture, and Department of Defense. The curr_chunk provides a list of different types of land under the jurisdiction of various federal agencies, including tribal lands, State and private lands, and lands within Mexico and Canada. The curr_chunk outlines recommendations for strategic border security management based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. Recommendations for strategic border security management include comparative security analysis, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. Training for Customs and Border Protection agents on natural resource protection is required. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection training for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel assigned to plan or oversee the construction or operation of border security tactical infrastructure or to patrol land along or in the vicinity of a land border of the United States, as well as cultural resource training for Customs. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection and cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure construction or patrolling land near the US border. The Secretary, in cooperation with relevant tribal governments, provides training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure construction or patrolling land near the US border. Coordination ensures training is appropriate to the agency's mission and focused on achieving border security goals. When providing training for border security personnel, the Secretary coordinates with relevant tribal governments to ensure it aligns with agency missions and focuses on achieving border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. This section focuses on improving operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security must gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, following the border protection strategy. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact enforcement techniques. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prioritize using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact enforcement techniques for border control. Consultation with various government agencies and entities is required. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with various government agencies, private property owners, and tribal governments to minimize the impact on the environment and communities near border enforcement sites. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with government agencies, private property owners, and tribal governments in the United States to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life for communities near border enforcement sites. This subsection does not create or negate any right of action for affected entities or impact eminent domain laws. The subsection does not create or negate any right of action for affected entities or impact eminent domain laws. It also does not require the Secretary of Homeland Security to install specific security measures. The subsection allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to waive other laws and does not require specific security measures to be installed along the international border if deemed ineffective. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive the use of barriers, roads, lighting, cameras, or sensors along the international border if deemed ineffective or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive the construction of fencing, barriers, roads, lighting, cameras, sensors, or other tactical infrastructure along the border if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. The Secretary of Homeland Security must not start any construction of border infrastructure until 90 days after submitting the required border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan will include measures to mitigate environmental impacts. The mitigation plan required under subsection (a) shall include measures to address and mitigate ecological and environmental impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders, such as preserving wildlife migration corridors and key habitats. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure must address ecological impacts, including preserving wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, and functional connectivity between habitats. It should also control invasive species and maintain hydrological functionality. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure must address ecological impacts, including preserving wildlife migration corridors, controlling invasive species, maintaining hydrological functionality, incorporating adaptive management, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure includes provisions for long-term monitoring, necessary adjustments based on monitoring results, and protection of cultural and historical resources. The Secretary has the authority to implement the plan on various types of lands near international borders. The Secretary has the authority to carry out a mitigation plan on Federal, State, local, tribal, or private lands near international borders, regardless of ownership or responsibility. Activities must adhere to specified conditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to carry out activities related to an international land border of the United States, in consultation with the owner or entity responsible for the management of the lands. The Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities under their programs, with consultation and concurrence of the land owner or responsible entity. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands managed by those agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands managed by agencies, exempt from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary may accept donations for developing and implementing the required mitigation plan on Federal lands managed by agencies. Transferred funds are exempt from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary can accept donations for developing and implementing a mitigation plan on Federal lands. Transferred funds are exempt from reprogramming requirements and can be used for border security infrastructure and activities. Authorization of Appropriations: Funds allocated to the Department of Homeland Security for border security can be utilized by the Secretary to create and execute the required mitigation plan.
